articles.headline: Fed Ties New Aid to Jobs Recovery in Forceful Move
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve opened a new chapter in its efforts to stimulate the American economy, saying that it intends to buy large quantities of mortgage bonds until the job market improves substantially.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve opened a new chapter in its efforts to stimulate the American economy, saying that it intends to buy large quantities of mortgage bonds until the job market improves substantially.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve opened a new chapter Thursday in its efforts to stimulate the economy, saying that it intends to buy large quantities of mortgage bonds, and potentially other assets, until the job market improves substantially.

articles.headline: Taking Pointers From Web Sites, USA Today Modernizes Its Look
articles.snippet: The Gannett-owned newspaper will look more like a Web site and its new Web site will read more like an iPad.
articles.abstract: The Gannett-owned newspaper will look more like a Web site and its new Web site will read more like an iPad.
articles.lead_paragraph: McLEAN, Va. — It’s face-lift time for the newspaper known for its pie charts.

articles.headline: A Tax Tactic That’s Open to Question
articles.snippet: Private equity’s use of carried interest to lower tax bills, though legal, has drawn criticism. But another lesser-known method might not withstand an I.R.S. challenge.
articles.abstract: Private equity’s use of carried interest to lower tax bills, though legal, has drawn criticism. But another lesser-known method might not withstand an I.R.S. challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Anyone may arrange his affairs so that his taxes shall be as low as possible; he is not bound to choose that pattern which best pays the treasury. There is not even a patriotic duty to increase one’s taxes.”

articles.headline: Uneasy Allies in the Grocery Aisle
articles.snippet: A ballot measure to require labeling of foods that contain genetically modified ingredients is putting organic brands like Kashi, owned by Kellogg, at odds with their owners.
articles.abstract: A ballot measure to require labeling of foods that contain genetically modified ingredients is putting organic brands like Kashi, owned by Kellogg, at odds with their owners.
articles.lead_paragraph: Giant bioengineering companies like Monsanto and DuPont are spending millions of dollars to fight a California ballot initiative aimed at requiring the labeling of genetically modified foods. That surprises no one, least of all the proponents of the law, which if approved by voters would become the first of its kind in the nation.

articles.headline: Off-Script Scramble for Power in a Chinese Leader’s Absence
articles.snippet: If and when China’s presumptive new leader, Xi Jinping, re-emerges, he will do so in the midst of a contentious Communist Party preparing to shake up its leadership.
articles.abstract: If and when China’s presumptive new leader, Xi Jinping, re-emerges, he will do so in the midst of a contentious Communist Party preparing to shake up its leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — With still no sign of China’s designated new leader, Xi Jinping, who has not been seen in public since Sept. 1, many insiders and well-connected analysts say the Chinese political ship is adrift, with factions jockeying to shape an impending Communist Party conclave.
articles.byline: By Ian Johnson and Jonathan Ansfield

articles.headline: Egypt, Hearing From Obama, Moves to Heal Rift From Protests
articles.snippet: A blunt phone call from President Obama prompted Egyptian leaders to scramble Thursday to try to repair the country’s alliance with Washington.
articles.abstract: A blunt phone call from President Obama prompted Egyptian leaders to scramble Thursday to try to repair the country’s alliance with Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Following a blunt phone call from President Obama, Egyptian leaders scrambled Thursday to try to repair the country’s alliance with Washington, tacitly acknowledging that they erred in their response to the attack on the United States Embassy by seeking to first appease anti-American domestic opinion without offering a robust condemnation of the violence.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Helene Cooper and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Fossil Fuel Industry Ads Dominate TV Campaign
articles.snippet: Major fossil fuel companies are financing an effort to defeat President Obama, while his former allies in promoting wind and solar power are disenchanted and sitting out the campaign.
articles.abstract: Major fossil fuel companies are financing an effort to defeat President Obama, while his former allies in promoting wind and solar power are disenchanted and sitting out the campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Barack Obama first ran for president, being green was so popular that oil companies like Chevron were boasting about their commitment to renewable energy, and his Republican opponent, John McCain, supported action on global warming.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Born to Be Wild, Aging Bikers Settle for Comfy
articles.snippet: When motorcyclists have trouble meeting the physical demands of a bike, many decide that it might be time to add a third wheel.
articles.abstract: When motorcyclists have trouble meeting the physical demands of a bike, many decide that it might be time to add a third wheel.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNT AIRY, N.C. — In his nearly 50 years as an avid motorcyclist, Grady Howard has roared down the tobacco roads of North Carolina and through the mountains of old Kentucky, all with his wife, Barbara, tucked behind him. But with a balky left leg and myriad other maladies, he knew the only way to stay wild was to add a wheel.

articles.headline: Anti-American Protests Flare Beyond the Mideast
articles.snippet: Anti-American rage that began over a video insult to Islam spread to nearly 20 countries in the Middle East and beyond.
articles.abstract: Anti-American rage that began over a video insult to Islam spread to nearly 20 countries in the Middle East and beyond.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anti-American rage that began this week over a video insult to Islam spread to nearly 20 countries across the Middle East and beyond on Friday, with violent and sometimes deadly protests that convulsed the birthplaces of the Arab Spring revolutions, breached two more United States Embassies and targeted diplomatic properties of Germany and Britain.

articles.headline: Bailed Out by Obama, but Rooting for Romney
articles.snippet: Even Wentzville, Mo., where a new General Motors plant is under construction, is expected to favor Mitt Romney, who opposed saving the automaker.
articles.abstract: Even Wentzville, Mo., where a new General Motors plant is under construction, is expected to favor Mitt Romney, who opposed saving the automaker.
articles.lead_paragraph: If there’s anywhere President Obama should expect to get a boost from the success of the government’s rescue of General Motors, it’s Wentzville, Mo., and Lordstown, Ohio.

articles.headline: New York Stock Exchange Settles Case Over Early Data Access
articles.snippet: The New York Stock Exchange agreed to adopt new internal controls and pay a $5 million penalty to settle accusations that its trading data gave select clients a split-second advantage.
articles.abstract: The New York Stock Exchange agreed to adopt new internal controls and pay a $5 million penalty to settle accusations that its trading data gave select clients a split-second advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the latest federal action against a major exchange, the New York Stock Exchange settled accusations on Friday that its trading data gave select clients a split-second advantage over retail investors.
